PROJECTS.TITLE: Project questions
PROJECTS.Q4: Which machine learning models are trained on your computer, and which are trained in the cloud?
PROJECTS.Q4-A-1: text projects can only be trained in the cloud.
PROJECTS.Q4-A-2: numbers projects can only be trained in the cloud.
PROJECTS.Q4-A-3: sounds projects can only be trained on your computer.
PROJECTS.Q4-A-4: images projects can be trained on your computer, or (if you have access to Watson Visual Recognition) in the cloud.

SCRATCH.TITLE: Scratch の問題
SCRATCH.Q1: Scratchが動作するようにする方法が分からない
SCRATCH.Q1-A-1: Machine Learning for Kidsは、Scratch 2を利用しています。Scratchが動作するには、Adobe Flashが必要なため、Flashが動作するウェブブラウザとOSの組み合わせを利用する必要があります。 (このため残念ながら iPads では動作しません。)
SCRATCH.Q1-A-2: Flashを利用可能にする方法が分からない場合は、Scratchを動作させるようにするためのヒントに関する文章をダウンロードしてください。
SCRATCH.Q2: The Scratch内の "Load Project" と "Save Project" メニューが動作しない。
SCRATCH.Q2-A-1: もし、MacOS上でSafariを利用していて、Scratchのメニュー "File -> Load Project" と "File -> Save Project" メニューが動作しない場合、もしかするとSafe Modeで動作させている可能性があります。
SCRATCH.Q2-A-2: どうのようにチェックして問題解決するかは、ここにある手順に従ってください。
SCRATCH.Q3: Scratch 内のMachine learning classifierブロックが動作しない
SCRATCH.Q3-A-1: 稀に, 機械学習モデル用のScratchブロックとサーバとのコネクションが切れることがあります。これが起きると、ブロックが結果を返さなくなります。
SCRATCH.Q3-A-2: この状態が発生しているのか発生しているのかを "More Blocks" palette内にあるステータスライトで確認できます。
SCRATCH.Q3-A-3: もし、このMachine Learning Scratch Block の並びにあるステータスライトが赤の場合、通常何か問題があることを示しています。一時的な問題の可能性もあります。あなたのプロジェクトを保存し ('ファイル' -> '直ちに保存'を使って), それから、ブラウザのページをリロードしてください。もしステータスライトが緑になったら、あなたのプロジェクトを読み込み ('ファイル' -> 'コンピュータから読み込む'を使って) 、保存した所から再開してください。
SCRATCH.Q3-A-4: もし、ステータスライトがリロードしても赤のままの場合、恐らく機械学習モデルに問題があると思われます。"学習とテスト" のページに行き、あなたのモデルに関するエラーが出ていないか確認ください。
SCRATCH.Q3-A-5: もし、machine learning Scratch blocksの隣のステータスライトが緑なら、ブロックは機能するハズです。 もし、期待しているレスポンスが得られない場合は、"学習とテスト" のページに行き、あなたのモデルがどのような結果を返すか確認してください。
SCRATCH.Q5: どのバージョンのScratchでも使えますか？
SCRATCH.Q5-A-1: このサイトが提供しているScratchのバージョンを利用する必要があります。Scratchをクリックすることで自動的に起動されます。又は、あなたのプロジェクトページから'Scratch 3'を選択することで起動します。
SCRATCH.Q6: Scratch 3 がプロジェクトを 'Downloads' フォルダーにのみ保存する
SCRATCH.Q6-A-1: あなたが 'File' -> 'Save to your computer' と Scratch 3でクリックすると, あなたの Scratch は、プロジェクトをあなたのコンピュータ保存します。
SCRATCH.Q6-A-2: 何人かの先生が、この際にプロジェクトが Downloads フォルダー（生徒がWindowsの Downloadフォルダーにアクセス権限がなくても）に保存ざれたと報告しています。結果的に、生徒は保存したプロジェクトにアクセスできませんでした。
SCRATCH.Q6-A-3: もし、この問題に直面した場合、ブラウザの設定を確認ください。ダウンロード関連で、「ファイルごとに保存先を指定する」というような設定があります。この設定を選択すると、あなたの生徒は、プロジェクトの保存先を選択できるようになります。

TRAININGUI.TITLE: トレーニングのUI関連
TRAININGUI.Q1: 画像プロジェクトで画像をトレーニング グループにドラッグすることができません。
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-1: 画像をトレーニンググループにドラッグする機能は、Internet Explorerでは機能しません。
TRAININGUI.Q1-A-2: もし、FirefoxやChromeが使えるなら、これらのブラウザを利用してください。それが出来ない場合は、代わりに "www" ボタンをクリックしトレーニングしたい画像のURLを張り付けてください。

MODELS.TITLE: 機械学習モデルトレーニングに関するエラー
MODELS.Q1: "No Watson credentials have been set up"
MODELS.Q1-A-1: このツールの機械学習モデルは、IBM Watson APIを使って作られています。
MODELS.Q1-A-2: もしあなたが "unmanaged" クラスのアカウントを持っているなら、あなたの先生又はグループリーダーは、IBM CLoudで取得したWatson API credentialsをこのツールに登録する必要があります。どのようにクレデンシャルを取得して登録するのかのステップ毎の手順説明した文章がこのページのトップの "Getting Started"にあります。
MODELS.Q2: "Watson credentials being used by your class were rejected"
MODELS.Q2-A-1: このツールの機械学習モデルは、IBM Watson APIを使って作られています。
MODELS.Q2-A-2: もしあなたが "unmanaged" クラスのアカウントを持っているなら、 あなたの先生又はグループリーダーは、このページのトップの "Getting Started"で説明されているようにIBM CLoudで取得した有効なWatson API credentialsをこのツールに登録する必要があります。
MODELS.Q2-A-3: しかしながら、現在提供されているクレデンシャルには問題があります。最も可能性の高い原因は、そのクレデンシャルが一旦IBM Cloudから提供された後で、削除されている場合です。もし、そうでなければ、Watsonのクレデンシャルを登録した先生やグループのリーダーは、IBM Cloud ダッシュボードで彼らが作成した Watson Assistant や Visual Recognition service 用のクレデンシャルの状況をチェックする必要があります。
MODELS.Q3: "Watson Assistant API keys have no more skills available"
MODELS.Q3-A-1: このツールの機械学習モデルは、IBM Watson APIを使って作られています。
MODELS.Q3-A-2: 先生によって作られた Watson Assistant (旧 Watson Conversation) クレデンシャルは利用できる機械学習モデルの数に制限があります。これは、クレデンシャルを作成する際に利用した IBM Cloud UI に "skills"として表示されています。
MODELS.Q3-A-3: もしこの制限を超えてしまったら、新しい機械学習モデルをトレーニングしようとする試みは失敗し、このメッセージが表示されます。
MODELS.Q3-A-4: あなたのクラスは既に最大許容数のモデルを作成しています。先生かグループリーダーに彼らの "Watson Assistant API keys have no more skills available"と知らせてください。
MODELS.Q3-A-5: もし、トレーニングに成功したモデルを持っている生徒がいたら、そのモデルを削除することで、ワークスペースを他の生徒のために開放することができます。
MODELS.Q3-A-6: クラスサイズを小さくすることで、将来このエラーが起きるのを防止することが可能です。もし、Watson Assistant (旧 Conversation) クレデンシャルがサポートしているWorkspaceの数より生徒数が少なければ、この問題は発生しません。
MODELS.Q3-A-7: この問題を回避する他の方法としては、追加の Watson Assistant API キーをクラスに追加するか、上限のより大きなプランの Watson Assistant インスタンス利用する方法があります。
MODELS.Q5: "Watson ... is currently rate limiting their API key"
MODELS.Q5-A-1: ツール内の機械学習モデルは、IBM Watson APIsを使って作られています。
MODELS.Q5-A-2: もし、あなたが "unmanaged" のクラスアカウントをお持ちの場合は、あなたの先生かグループリーダーは、この作業をするためには、IBM Cloudから取得したWatson API クレデンシャルを提供する必要があります。
MODELS.Q5-A-3: 無償のアカウントを利用している場合、新しい機械学習モデルのためのリクエストの頻度に制限があります。通常の利用では問題ありません。しかし、もし生徒が上記で説明した "no more skills available" や "no more classifiers available" エラーが出ていても、"Train new Machine Learning model" ボタンを数分押し続けた場合、この制限の対象となります。
MODELS.Q5-A-4: その場合は、以下のようなメッセージが生徒の画面に表示されます:
MODELS.Q5-A-5: あなたのクラスは、機械学習モデルを作成するリクエストを制限を超えて早いペースで出し過ぎています。今すぐリクエストを出すのを中止し、先生又はグループリーダーに "the Watson Assistant service is currently rate limiting their API key"だと通知してください。
MODELS.Q5-A-6: この制限はこのサイト（Machine Learning for Kids）には通常適用されず、一時的なものです。しばらく待つことでこの制限は解除されます。
MODELS.Q5-A-7: もし、生徒が "Train new Machine Learning model" ボタンを押した時に上記で説明した "no more skills available" や "no more classifiers available" エラーが出た場合は、彼らに問題は解決しておらず、状況を悪くしていると通知してください。
MODELS.Q6: とても長い時間モデルがトレーンングされるのを待っています。
MODELS.Q6-A-1: ページをリフレッシュしてください。
MODELS.Q6-A-2: 30秒毎に機械学習モデルの状況を確認しようとしますが、例外的にチェックが何らかの理由で止まる場合があります。このため、既に利用可能な状況になっている可能性があります。
MODELS.Q6-A-3: もし、3分以上経っているなら、リフレッシュ・リロードしてみてください。
MODELS.Q6-A-4: もし、10分以上経っているなら、再トレーニングすることを考えてください。（Cancel ボタンを押して、新しいモデルをトレーニングボタンを再度押す)
MODELS.Q7: "Your class is sharing Watson API keys ... there are currently none available"
MODELS.Q7-A-1: Machine learning models in the tool are created using IBM Watson APIs.
MODELS.Q7-A-2: If you have a "managed" class account, this means your class is sharing these keys with many other schools.
MODELS.Q7-A-3: There are normally enough for all schools, but if it is very busy and all of the available API keys are currently in use, attempts to train new machine learning models will fail, and this message will be displayed:
MODELS.Q7-A-4: Your class is sharing Watson Assistant / Visual Recognition "API keys" with many other schools, and unfortunately there are currently none available. Please let your teacher or group leader know that you will have to train your machine learning model later
MODELS.Q7-A-5: If a student who has a successfully trained model then deletes their model, this will free up a skill for use by another student.
MODELS.Q7-A-6: The best thing to do is to try again later, after other students have deleted their machine learning models and API keys are available again. Your training data will still be safe until then.
MODELS.Q7-A-7: Another way to avoid this error is for your class to create an "unmanaged" class account, which is where a teacher creates their own Watson "API keys" that can be dedicated only for use by their own class.

TEACHERUI.TITLE: 先生・管理者 UI 関連
TEACHERUI.Q2: 先生用ページ内リストで生徒アカウントが不明
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-1: Machine Learning for Kids の生徒管理はサードパーティー Auth0.のサービスを利用しています。
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-2: 稀に, Auth0が返してくる生徒の情報が古い場合があり、最近追加された生徒が反映されていない（同様に最近削除した生徒が表示されている）場合があります。
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-3: そのような場合でも、通常は、生徒情報は正常に作成（又は削除）されており、単に最近の変更が生徒のリストに反映されていないだけです。
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-4: Auth0 は通常そのような問題を、そのステータスページで user indexing delays or problems with their Search APIで報告しています。
TEACHERUI.Q2-A-5: このような場合は、Auth0 のインデクス後進が最新状況を反映するまで待つのがベストな対応になります。
TEACHERUI.Q4: 何故、機械学習モデルは自動的に削除されるのですか?
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-1: これは、Machine Learning for Kidsを最初に使った学校からの要望でした。一つのクラスが使える機械学習モデルの数に常に制限があることから来ています。 この機能がこの制限の中で運用するのを容易にしています。
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-2: 生徒にクラス終了後にクリーンナップと（次のクラスがモデルを作成できるように）彼らのモデルの削除をさせる代わりに、ツールがクラス終了後に自動的にモデルを削除し、クリーンナップします。これがクラスとクラスの間のクリーンナップ処理を省きクラスを実施するのを容易にします。
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-3: モデルが削除されるまでの時間は設定可能です。授業時間が１時間か2時間の学校の場合、2時間後にモデルを削除するように設定するのが良いでしょう。一週間続きのコーディングクラブの場合、6日後に削除するのが次のセッションを確実に実施するのに良いでしょう。
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-4: あなたのクラスの時間制限を 制限ページs section of your Teacher page.
TEACHERUI.Q4-A-6: 注意事項: 機械学習モデルだけが自動的に削除され、トレーニングのためのデータは削除されません。もし、生徒がまだ作業中のモデルが自動的に削除された場合でも, 彼らは "Train" ボタンをクリックするだけでモデルを再作成できます。

ACCOUNTISSUES.TITLE: アカウント関連
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1: アカウントを作成するのと、 "Try it now"の違いはなんですか?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-1: "Try it now" を利用するとログインするしたり、アカウントを作成したりする必要はありません。思い出す必要のあるパスワードもありません。また、先生が個人情報を提供する必要もありません。 また、この方法は、先生が生徒のアカウントを管理する手間も省くことが可能です。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-2: しかし、アカウントを作成することで追加機能を利用できます。生徒は彼らの成果を保存でき、後日のレッスンで利用できます。彼らは他の生徒と一緒にプロジェクトを実施できます。そして、家からログインして家族に成果をみせることも可能です。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q1-A-3: 以下に違いをまとめています。
ACCOUNTISSUES.TRAINMODELS: 機械学習モデルを以下を認識するためにトレーニング
ACCOUNTISSUES.SAVE_PROJECTS: プロジェクトの保存と読込み
ACCOUNTISSUES.WORK_ON_PROJECTS: 機械学習モデルを利用
ACCOUNTISSUES.UNTIL_DELETION: あなたが削除するまで
ACCOUNTISSUES.ONE_COMPUTER: 一つのコンピュータから
ACCOUNTISSUES.ONLINE: オンラインでどこからでも
ACCOUNTISSUES.WITH_CLASSMATES: クラスメートと一緒に
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2: クラスアカウントを作成しましたが、先生のログインでログインできません。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-1: ログオンできるようになる前に、あなたは、あなたのEmailアドレスを確認する必要があります。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-2: クラスアカウントを作成時、あなたが提供したEmailアドレスに確認用のリンクを含むメールを送信します。このリンクをクリックすることでEmailアドレスが確認され、クラスアカウントが利用可能になり、ログインできるようになります。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-3: もし、確認用のメールをまだ見ていないのであれば、スパムフォルダーに入っていないか確認してください。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q2-A-4: 見つけられない場合は、私に英語でお知らせください。 問題解決できるよう支援します。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-2: 生徒は彼らのアカウントを削除できません。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-3: 先生は削除したい生徒のアカウントをいつでも "Teacher" ページから生徒のアカウントの隣にある "Delete student account" ボタンをクリックすることで削除できます。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-4: アカウントを削除すると生徒の全てのデータ、プロジェクトと機械学習モデルが削除されます。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-5: 削除後の復元は不可能です。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-7: 先生アカウントを削除すると、クラスとクラス中の全ての生徒のアカウントも削除され、復元することはできません。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q3-A-8: 先生アカウントの削除はyour Teacher pageにあるAdvanced optioins sections内の "Delete Class" ボタンをクリックすると削除されます。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4: 利用者に関してどのような情報が保存されますか?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-2: アカウント作成時に入力されたユーザ名とemailアドレスは、今後の連絡用に保存されています。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-4: 生徒アカウント用のユーザ名は、ログイン用に保存されています。本サイトは、生徒のEmailアドレスや連絡情報は保持していません。また、生徒を特定できるその他の情報も保持していません。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-5: 本サイトは、 生徒にstudent1のような一般的なユーザ名を付与することを推奨しています。 そうすることで学校やコーディンググループ外で特定されることを防げます。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-6: 全てのアカウントについて保存される一般的な情報
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-7: 本サイトの利用者管理は、サードパーティAuth0のサービスを利用して実装されており、あなたが本サイトにアクセスした最後の　IP アドレス、ブラウザのタイプを保存しています。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-8: Webブラウザで発生したエラーは、サードパーティのサービスSentryを用いて取得されます。もし不都合が発生したら、エラーに関する情報（ユーザ名、IPアドレス、ブラウザタイプ、不都合に関する技術的な説明）を取得します。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q4-A-9: 本サイトでは Google Analytics を利用状況を把握するのに利用しています。このツールは地理的な情報やブラウザのタイプ等の情報を収集しますが、集約した情報のみを表示します。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5: 生徒が作成したトレーニングデータはどうなりますか?
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-1: 本サイトで生徒が作成する機械学習プロジェクトはトレーニングデータを作成・収集します。文字列プレジェクトでは, 短い文字列をタイプすることを意味しますし、画像プロジェクトでは、Webcamで写真を撮ったり、スクリーン上のキャンバスに絵を描いたりすることを意味し、数値プロジェクトでは、数値のセットを入力することを意味します。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-2: これらの全てのトレーニングデータは、IBMにホストされている MySQL データベース Cloudに格納されます。本サイトのデータベースの管理者は、生徒が作成した全てのトレーニング例にアクセスできます。 しかし、本サイトでは生徒が彼らのプロジェクトのためにアクセスし、作業する以外の目的で利用しません。本サイトは、トレーニングデータを（公にも、個人にも、第三者にも）公開しません。２つの例外は、以下に説明されている２つのIBM Watson APIを用いるために送信することです。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-3: 文字列プロジェクトのための機械学習モデルは、IBM Watson Assistant クラウドサービスを用いて作られており、生徒がモデルをトレーニングする際に、生徒が入力したトレーニングデータのコピーは、 IBM Watsonに送信されます。 IBM Watsonは、これらのトレーニングデータを他目的には利用しません。これは、本サイト(Machine Learning for Kids)が、IBMがサービス改善のために生徒が入力したトレーニングデータを利用することからオプトアウト しているからです。詳細は、Watsonのドキュメントを参照ください。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-4: 画像プロジェクトのための機械学習モデルは、 IBM Visual Recognition　クラウドサービスを用いて作成されており、 生徒がモデルをトレーニングする際に、生徒が入力したトレーニングデータのコピーは、 IBM Watsonにアップロードされます。 IBM Watsonは、これらのトレーニングデータを他目的には利用しません。これは、本サイト(Machine Learning for Kids)が、IBMがサービス改善のために生徒が入力したトレーニングデータを利用することから オプトアプト しているからです。 詳細は、Watsonのドキュメントを参照ください。
ACCOUNTISSUES.Q5-A-5: IBM Watsonは、かれらのサービスとトレーニングデータを共有する一般的なガイダンスを提供しています。それらは、本サイトで生成・収集されたトレーニングデータにも適用されます。特に、生徒には個人が特定できるような情報を彼らが収集するトレーニングデータに含めないようにアドバイスしてください。

APIKEYSGUIDE.TITLE: Guide to IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Teachers / parents / code club-leaders with unmanaged class accounts need to provide 'API Keys' from IBM Cloud. These are secret codes that provide access to the artificial intelligence technology that will power student projects.
INTRO.INTRO_2: Text projects need a 'Watson Assistant' API Key. (Images, numbers and sound projects don't require API Keys).
INTRO.INTRO_3: You will need to create an account on IBM Cloud to be able to create these codes. It is free to create an account, and there are no charges for 'Lite' API Keys.

APIKEYSGUIDE.EXPLANATION: Download a step-by-step guide for how to create API Keys on IBM Cloud

INTRO.INTRO_1: Machine Learning for Kids provides pre-trained models you can use in your projects. Real-world machine learning projects often use models already trained by other people. There are lots of well-trained models that are freely available, and these are useful when you don't have time to collect the amount of training data needed to train your own.

HOWTO.TITLE: How to use
HOWTO.INTRO: Click on the button to go to Scratch.
HOWTO.HOW_1: Go to the version of Scratch 3 available from Machine Learning for Kids.
HOWTO.HOW_2: Pre-trained models are available from the Extensions panel. Click on the blue extensions button in the bottom-left of the Scratch window to find them, then click on the one you want to add to your project.
HOWTO.HOW_3: The blocks for the pre-trained model will be added to the Scratch toolbox.

SPEECHTOTEXT.TITLE: Speech to text
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_1: This model can be used to recognize speech recorded through your microphone.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_2: It gives you a block you can use to record some audio and then give you the text that it recognized, and a block that you can tell it to listen out for a particular word or phrase.
SPEECHTOTEXT.SPEECH_3: It uses the speech recognition capability that comes with Google Chrome, so the ML model that you'll be using comes from Google. (It also means that you can only use this model if you're using the Google Chrome web browser, sorry!)

FACEAPI.TITLE: Face detection
FACEAPI.FACE_1: This model can be used to recognize your face in the video feed from your webcam.
FACEAPI.FACE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of your eyes, nose and mouth.
FACEAPI.FACE_3: This uses a top-down technique - it starts by looking for something that looks like a face in the picture. Once it has found that, it tries to identify facial features in that area. The machine learning model is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
FACEAPI.FACE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as WIDER FACE.

POSENET.TITLE: Pose detection
POSENET.POSE_1: This model can be used to recognize your pose in the video feed from your webcam.
POSENET.POSE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of different parts of your body, like shoulders, elbows, wrists, knees, and ankles.
POSENET.POSE_3: This uses a bottom-up technique - looking for human body key points (like shoulders, elbows, knees, etc.) and then grouping them to identify a person and the pose that they're in.
POSENET.POSE_4: The training data used for this model came from a set known as Common Objects in Context (COCO).
POSENET.POSE_5: For more information, including a description of some of the challenges and potential issues with the model, see the model card.

HANDPOSE.TITLE: Hand detection
HANDPOSE.POSE_1: This model can be used to recognize your hand in the video feed from your webcam.
HANDPOSE.POSE_2: It gives you blocks that will find the x,y coordinates of different parts of your hand: the tips of each of your fingers, and your wrist.
HANDPOSE.POSE_3: It can only return information about one hand in the view.
HANDPOSE.POSE_4: For more information, including a description of some of the challenges and potential issues with the model, see the model card.

TOXICITY.TITLE: Toxicity
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_1: This model can be used to recognize whether text contains toxic content.
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_2: It gives you blocks that will predict the percentage probability that some provided text contains toxic content such as threatening language, insults, obscenities, or identity-based hate.
TOXICITY.TOXICITY_3: The training data used for this model came from two-million user-generated comments posted on news articles.

IMAGENET.TITLE: Imagenet
IMAGENET.IMAGENET_1: This model can be used to recognize objects in a costume.
IMAGENET.IMAGENET_2: It gives you blocks that will predict the main object shown in a sprite.
IMAGENET.IMAGENET_3: It has been trained to recognize photos of one-thousand common objects. The machine learning model is based on MobileNet (a ML model designed for mobile devices, so it doesn't need much computing power).
IMAGENET.IMAGENET_4: It has been trained to recognize photos, and won't recognize cartoons or drawings very well.

QNA.TITLE: Question Answering
QNA.QNA_1: This model can be used to find answers to questions.
QNA.QNA_2: It gives you a block that will look for the answer to a question in some text that you give it.
QNA.QNA_3: It is a type of machine learning model called BERT which is useful for projects with text.
QNA.QNA_4: It has been trained using a set of questions and answers from Wikipedia articles collected by Stanford University called 'SQuAD'.
QNA.QNA_5: This is a complex model, so you might find that it is slow and needs a lot of memory on your computer!

SPICE.TITLE: Pitch estimation
SPICE.SPICE_1: This model can be used to recognize a note being sung from your computer's microphone.
SPICE.SPICE_2: It gives you blocks that will return the frequency of a note it recognized, and to convert that into the name or MIDI note.
SPICE.SPICE_3: The model, called SPICE, has been trained to identify the dominant pitch in sung audio, including being able to recognize a sung note even if there is background music and noise.
SPICE.SPICE_4: The training data used for this model came from MIR-1K, which is a set of 1000 short sound recordings of amateur singers singing along to karaoke.
SPICE.SPICE_5: You will need to let Scratch use your microphone to use this model.

IDEAS.IDEAS_1: Are there other machine learning models you would like to be able to use in your Scratch projects?
IDEAS.IDEAS_2: Let me know by asking in the ML for Kids forum.

TENSORFLOW.TITLE: TensorFlow
TENSORFLOW.TF_1: TensorFlow is a toolkit for training and running machine learning models.
TENSORFLOW.TF_2: If you know how to create your own machine learning model with TensorFlow, click the button above to use it in Scratch.
TENSORFLOW.TF_3: You can build your own model, using programming languages like Python.
TENSORFLOW.TF_4: Or you can use tools like Teachable Machine to easily train a TensorFlow model, and then make something with it in Scratch here.
TENSORFLOW.TF_5: (Only image classifiers are supported today, but support for more types of machine learning model is coming soon!)

BOOK.TITLE: Book
BOOK.NOTES_1: Machine Learning for Kids : A Project-Based Introduction to Artificial Intelligence is a new book to accompany the site.
BOOK.NOTES_2: The book is a guided hands-on and practical introduction to how artificial intelligence impacts our lives. It includes step-by-step instructions for making a variety of machine learning-powered projects in Scratch, and explains how they each relate to real-world AI applications.
BOOK.NOTES_3: Several projects dive deeper into particular aspects of how machine learning is applied, including recreating some of the most common mistakes made in AI, and learning about the different ways that the performance of machine learning systems can be measured and described.
BOOK.NOTES_4: Finally, the book ends by recreating examples of biased machine learning systems, and discusses the AI ethics issues that they raise.

UPDATES.TITLE: Updates and corrections
UPDATES.NOTES: Any updates or corrections will be posted here. For more help, please see the Help page.

STORIES.TITLE: What students learn about AI/ML
STORIES.DOWNLOAD: Download instructions to create this project

INTRO.TEXT1: The goal of Machine Learning for Kids is to help students learn about artificial intelligence and machine learning. This is done by providing opportunities to make things using machine learning technologies.
INTRO.TEXT2: When given time and freedom to build and experiment with machine learning in a familiar sandbox like Scratch, students discover a lot about how this technology is applied and behaves.
INTRO.TEXT3: These stories are examples: examples of what students observed, what they did, and what they learned. These are useful insights for planning how to introduce AI/ML in the classroom.
INTRO.TEXT4: If you have your own story, please consider contributing it.

EXAMPLES.VIDEO: 🎥 See the video for an example.

MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TITLE: Machine learning hasn't replaced the need to learn to code
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT1: I like to introduce students to machine learning by allowing them to make things with pretrained models - a range of new blocks that can be added to the Scratch palette to represent a variety of powerful machine learning models.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT2: For example, imagenet: a model that can recognise the object in a photo that you give it. It can recognise over a thousand different things.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT3: With just a few Scratch blocks, students can start building projects that do remarkably powerful and impressive things.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT4: Another example is the face detection model: a model that can identify different parts of a face (e.g. eyes, nose, ears, etc.) in a picture or webcam view.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT5: With just a few Scratch blocks, students can make a fun face filter with animated sprites that follow their face.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT6: These are very simple projects to build, but they offer a lot of opportunity for experimentation and creativity.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT7: Learning about machine learning in a sandbox that students are already familiar with (rather than learn about AI/ML in a new AI-specific tool or platform) sends a clear message to students.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT8: Students shouldn't think that what they already learn about coding isn't useful any more. They shouldn't get the impression that learning to code is somehow less valuable because machine learning models will just magically do stuff for them in the future.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.TEXT9: Instead, students see that machine learning adds new tools to their existing toolbox. They see that what they've been learning about coding is still important and valuable, and that machine learning expands the types of things they're able to build.
MLHASNTREPLACEDCODING.CALLOUT: Building with machine learning in an existing sandbox like Scratch makes it clear that ML isn't separate to, or a replacement for, coding.

MLWORKFLOW.TITLE: Workflow of a machine learning project
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT1: If students are given the time and freedom to create their own machine learning models, rather than being given an existing model to use, they can learn even more.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT2: A major part of the Machine Learning for Kids site is a child-friendly training tool that can be used to create a wide range of machine learning models.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT3: For example, students can make their own simple chatbots, by training a text classifier to recognise frequently asked questions. They can choose their own subject for what the chatbot can answer questions about. In the video shown here, the student chose to make a project about the Moon.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT4: They have to guess what questions someone might ask about their subject. In the video shown, you can see the student thought someone might ask where the Moon is, how big it is, how cold it is on the Moon, or what it's made of.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT5: For each of those questions, they came up with a few examples of how someone might ask that question.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT6: They used those examples to train their own custom machine learning model, unique to their project.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT7: Then they scripted the responses that their chatbot should give when it gets a question that it has learned to recognise.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT8: I've run this project with school classes dozens of times, and it is different every time, with each class bringing their own creativity and imagination to the chatbot.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT9: I've helped history classes make chatbot Vikings, chatbot Romans, and chatbot Ancient Greeks - trained to answer about what it was like to live in their times, what they ate, what they wore, and so on.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT10: I've helped English classes have created chatbot Shakespeares that they trained to answer questions about his life and some of his most famous plays.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT11: I've helped school clubs create local chatbot guides about their own school or their own town, trained to answer questions about their local area.
MLWORKFLOW.TEXT12: By going through the process for themselves, they learn the workflow of a machine learning project - a workflow that is similar to real-world projects: predict what users might do; collect examples of how the user would do that; use those examples to train a machine learning model to recognise that; and script what the system should do in response when it recognises something.
MLWORKFLOW.CALLOUT: Going through the process of creating a machine learning project for themselves gives students an insight into how these systems are created in the real world.

TRAININGQUANTITY.TITLE: Collecting more training examples often improves accuracy
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT1: The video starts with one student's training data from their Pac-Man project. They played a simplified version of Pac-Man in Scratch.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT2: They set up the game in Scratch so that every time they pressed an arrow key ('left', 'right', 'up', or 'down') as well as moving their Pac-Man character, it put the x,y coordinates for Pac-Man and the Ghost into the training bucket for that direction.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT3: For example, when Pac-Man was at x=3,y=4 and the Ghost was at x=5,y=5 - they went right. That became a training example for when it's good to go right. and so on.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT4: They used these examples to train their own machine learning model to be able to play the game: a machine learning model that can predict when Pac-Man should go left, right, up, or down, (based on the current location of Pac-Man and the current location of the Ghost). Their goal is to train the game so that Pac-Man can play itself, without them having to touch any of the keys at all.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT5: Some students will be impatient - eager to try their model as soon as they can. Their machine-learning Pac-Man will play very badly at first.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT6: With only a few training examples, their Pac-Man might not have even learned enough to navigate the maze and can get stuck in a corner or against a wall.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT7: They go back and do a bit more training, and collect more training examples of them playing. With a few more examples, they see Pac-Man able to navigate the maze but it gets caught by the Ghost very quickly.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT8: They do even more training - collecting more examples, and they see their Pac-Man surviving a little longer.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT9: They play more and more, adding more training examples, and see their Pac-Man start to play well. By the end of the lesson, they've collected a large number of training examples, and some students will see their Pac-Man able to evade the Ghost forever.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT10: What these students stumble onto is the correlation between the amount of training data, and the accuracy of a machine learning model.
TRAININGQUANTITY.TEXT11: This is a crucial principle in applying machine learning technologies, but instead of being told that as a rule, students can discover this for themselves through observing the performance of their own machine learning model - noticing how it improves as they add more training examples.
TRAININGQUANTITY.CALLOUT: Giving students freedom to experiment with their machine learning model lets them learn for themselves about the relationship between the quantity of training data and the accuracy of machine learning models.

CROWDSOURCING.TITLE: Crowdsourcing and gamification can help to generate training data
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT1: I like running projects like Pac-Man (where students collect training examples by playing a game) with a class after they've done a project like chatbots (where students collect training examples by typing them in).
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT2: There will often by at least one (shamelessly honest!) student in the class who will tell me that typing in example questions to train a chatbot is 'boring'! And that they think creating training examples for Pac-Man by playing a video game is 'fun', 'easier', and just 'better'.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT3: This is a useful learning experience for the students, because - they're not wrong!
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT4: Collecting and labelling training examples in machine learning projects is a chore. It is often manual. It is repetitive. It is almost always time-consuming.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT5: But students do understand that projects need a lot of training examples to be successful.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT6: It's helpful to allow students to notice all of this for themselves, and encourage them to discuss the challenges this brings to real-world AI projects. I've seen classes have fascinating and constructive discussions once they realise that making the creation of training data into a game is one way to help.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT7: Games are an effective tool for teaching students about machine learning, and several of the project worksheets available through Machine Learning for Kids are based on games.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT8: For example, noughts and crosses (or tic tac toe) is a great basis for a project.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT9: As with Pac-Man, students play the game in Scratch, coding the game so that every time they make a move, the state of the game board is added to one of their training buckets.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT10: They can use these training examples to train a machine learning model to be able to play noughts and crosses.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT11: Students can do this individually, with each of them training their own custom machine learning model, and seeing how it behaves in response to their own training.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT12: I remember running one class where the students realised how much quicker and easier this would be if they worked together.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT13: Instead of each student setting up their own training buckets, they asked if they could have one set of training buckets for the whole class, that they all add training examples to.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT14: This was inspired. (At the time, I had to let them all share a username and password to do this, but it went so well I ended up modifying the site to support group/class projects.)
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT15: Thirty students can create training examples 30x times faster than one student working on their own.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT16: In the time available in one lesson, thirty students can create 30x as much training data as one student working alone.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT17: And (as students normally realise) the more training examples they can create, the better their model will be at playing the game.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT18: (In fact, this tends to improve the quality of the training data as well as quantity, because it tends to result in more varied examples. This is a nuance that students find easier to recognise in more visual projects.)
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT19: This sort of project planning are all key parts of planning a lot of successful real-world machine learning projects, whether it's finding ways to crowdsource the generation of training data, or to create training data as a by-product of something that people are already doing or that they would enjoy doing anyway.
CROWDSOURCING.TEXT20: Students understand the fundamentals for why this is done, and can often think of approaches like this themselves based on their first-hand experiences in the classroom.
CROWDSOURCING.CALLOUT1: Students can see for themselves how gamification is a great way to motivate people to create a lot of training data.
CROWDSOURCING.CALLOUT2: Students can see for themselves how crowd-sourcing the generation of training data is a great way to more easily create a large amount of training data.

VARIETY.TITLE: Increasing diversity of training data often improves accuracy
VARIETY.TEXT1: Students can make a Scratch project to play Rock, Paper, Scissors. They use their webcam to collect example photos of their hands making the shapes of 'rock' (fist), 'paper' (flat hand), and 'scissors' (two fingers). Then they use those photos to train a machine learning model to recognise their hand shapes.
VARIETY.TEXT2: I often have at least one enthusiastic (or impatient!) student keen to create their machine learning model as quickly as possible. They'll hold their hand fairly still in front of the webcam, and keep hitting the camera button. The result is that they'll take a large number of very similar photos.
VARIETY.TEXT3: Other students will naturally create a range of different photos. They'll take some photos of their left hand, and some photos of their right hand. They'll take some photos of their hand held very close to the webcam looking large in the photo, and they'll take some photos of their hand held far away from the webcam looking small. They'll take photos of their hand in a variety of directions, and from a variety of angles.
VARIETY.TEXT4: If left to experiment and encouraged to compare their projects, students will notice differences in the way that their different projects behave.
VARIETY.TEXT5: Projects trained with a wider variety of training examples often perform better. Their models make fewer mistakes and have a higher confidence score for hand shapes they recognise correctly.
VARIETY.TEXT6: Projects trained with a very similar set of training examples make more mistakes, particularly when students play each other's Rock, Paper, Scissors holding with their hand in a position or at an angle that was different to the way it was trained.
VARIETY.CALLOUT: Letting students try each other's project allows them to see that machine learning models trained with a wider variety of training examples perform better.

TESTDATA.TITLE: Training and test data should be kept separate
TESTDATA.TEXT1: I remember talking with a teacher about media literacy lessons they were doing with their class. The class was learning how different media outlets cover the news, not just which stories they choose to cover, but also the different language they use to describe the same stories
TESTDATA.TEXT2: The teacher wanted a way to consolidate what the students had learned, which got us thinking: could a computer learn to recognise the sorts of patterns they had been learning?
TESTDATA.TEXT3: And could we use an AI project to reinforce, and get the students to think about, what they'd been learning?
TESTDATA.TEXT4: I helped his class give it a try. They chose four national newspapers, and they worked together to collect examples of the top front-page headline for each newspaper across a few months.
TESTDATA.TEXT5: We used these examples to train a machine learning model.
TESTDATA.TEXT6: The next question was how the students could tell if the computer had learned to recognise the use of language in the different newspapers.
TESTDATA.TEXT7: They made a game in Scratch to test it: when they typed in a headline, the machine learning model predicted which newspaper that came from, and moved the newspaper to the right shelf.
TESTDATA.TEXT8: The students started by using the same headlines for this that they'd collected for training.
TESTDATA.TEXT9: I asked them if they thought that was a good test. They were confused by this, and didn't see where I was going with it at first.
TESTDATA.TEXT10: I used the tests and exams they do in school as an example. I asked them: 'Do your exams all have the exact same questions, written in the exact same wording, that you studied in class?'
TESTDATA.TEXT11: They said 'no, of course not'. So I asked them why not.
TESTDATA.TEXT12: With a little prompting, they described how they get new questions for exams they haven't seen before because that is a fairer way of seeing if they've really understood the idea rather than just memorized an answer.
TESTDATA.TEXT13: By this point, they had realized where I was going with this. And they started collecting new newspaper headlines for testing, that weren't already used in the training data.
TESTDATA.TEXT14: From their experience with this project, they learned that they needed to test with new and different headlines to really know if their machine learning model had learned how different newspapers use language.
TESTDATA.CALLOUT: Machine learning projects need to keep training and test data separate.

NOTJUSTINTENTS.TITLE: Machine learning can learn to recognize different types of patterns
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT1: Projects like chatbots can perhaps give students the impression that machine learning classifiers in text projects can only be used to recognise the meaning of text ('intent classification'). I like to run other projects with classes that I work with to show them the other ways that the tech can be used
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT2: 'Make Me Happy' is a nice example. I ask students to create two training buckets.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT3: In one bucket, they type examples of the nicest, kindest compliments they can think of.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT4: In the second bucket, they type examples of the meanest, cruellest insults they can think of.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT5: They use these examples to train a machine learning model to recognise the use of language in compliments as opposed to insults.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT6: They make a character in Scratch that reacts to what you say to it - and then test their model by sending compliments and insults to their character.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT7: (My favourite one of these was a student who drew a cartoon dog that would wag its tail when they said something nice to it, and looked sad when they said something mean to it! I don't have their artistic skill, so I used emojis instead)
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT8: I've seen projects like this get students thinking about the different ways that text classifiers can be used - such as recognising writing style (e.g. formal vs informal), sentiment (e.g. positive vs negative), as well as tone.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT9: This is a great jumping off point for engaging students with a discussion about how and where this technology should be used, such as marketing, human relations, and customer relations.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.TEXT10: Students are well placed to have discussions in how AI/ML technologies should be applied when they can draw on the insights from first-hand experiences of experimenting with these technologies.
NOTJUSTINTENTS.CALLOUT: Machine learning can learn to recognize a wide variety of types of patterns in text, not just the meaning or intent of the text.

COLLECTINGERRORS.TITLE: Collecting poorly handled inputs to add to training is a common practice
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT1: Digital assistants, such as Amazon's Alexa or Google's Home, is a great basis for student projects, because it is a use case that the students are familiar with.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT2: A project I've run many times is to help students create their own virtual assistant in Scratch, by training a machine learning model to recognise commands like "turn on a lamp". They do this by collecting examples of how they would phrase those commands.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT3: By the time I do this project, my classes will normally have learned that they need to test their machine learning model with examples they didn't use for training.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT4: Students like trying to break things - they enjoy looking for edge cases that will trip up the machine learning model. In this case, it can be unusual ways of phrasing commands that their model won't recognise.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT5: I remember one student came up with 'activate the spinny thing!' as a way of asking to turn on a fan, which I thought was inspired.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT6: But when the model gets something wrong, what should they do about that?
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT7: Students will normally suggest by themselves that a good thing to do is to collect examples of what their machine learning model gets wrong, and add those to one of their training buckets.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT8: That means every time it makes a mistake, they can add that to their training, and train a new model - and their model will get better at recognizing commands like that in future.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT9: They typically think of this for themselves, because with a little understanding about how machine learning technology behaves, this is a natural and obvious thing to do.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT10: But when Amazon was found to be doing this, maintsteam media was surprised.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT12: Many articles included journalists saying that they had no idea this was something a machine learning project might want to do.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT13: Students who've worked through a similar process for themselves can easily understand the motivation.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT14: This is not to say that students automatically think it's acceptable or appropriate.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT15: Most classes I've run are typically mixed on this issue: some students think it's reasonable, while others think it's inappropriate. And I've watched them have some fantastic debates about it.
COLLECTINGERRORS.TEXT16: The crucial thing is that they debate this in the context of an understanding of the technology, and an understanding of the motivation of the tech companies (an understanding that is often lacking in media reporting).
COLLECTINGERRORS.CALLOUT: First-hand experience with machine learning technologies gives students a crucial insight into the behaviour and motivations of tech companies.

CONFIDENCESCORES.TITLE: How to use confidence scores
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT1: Machine learning models don't just give an answer, they also typically return a score showing how confident the system is that it has correctly recognized the input.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT2: Knowing how to use this confidence score is an important part of using machine learning.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT3: An example of how a student used this in their project is shown in the video. Their Scratch script says that if the machine learning model has less than 50% confidence that it has correctly recognized a command, it replies "I'm sorry I don't understand" (instead of taking an action).
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT4: The project was trained to understand commands to turn on a lamp or a fan. When they asked it to "Make me a cheese sandwich", their assistant didn't try to turn the lamp or fan on, it said "I don't understand"
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT5: This command was unlike any of the example commands that had been used to train the model, causing the machine learning model to have a very low level of confidence that it had recognised the command. This was represented with a very low confidence score.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT6: The challenge for the students making this project was knowing what confidence score threshold to use. Instead of telling them a good value to use, I let them try out different values and decide for themselves. By playing and experimenting with it, they get a feel for the impact that this threshold has on their project.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT7: What they learned was that there isn't one "correct" confidence threshold that makes sense for all projects or for all machine learning models.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT8: What I mean is, they noticed that if they set the confidence threshold very very low, their assistant would almost always take an action. But it would do this even when it hadn't understood the command correctly, taking the wrong action.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT9: Conversely, if they set the confidence threshold very very high, their assistant would only take an action when it was very very confident that it had correctly recognized the command. The good thing was that, when it took an action, it rarely took the wrong action.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT10: But the bad thing was that it said "I don't understand" very often, even when actually it had correctly understood what they'd asked.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT11: It was fascinating hearing students describe their assistant configured like this as being too "shy" or "timid", and that it "didn't have enough self-confidence". My favourite description was a student who described their machine learning-powered assistant as being like when they don't put their hand up in class to answer a question, even when they actually knew the answer, but aren't confident enough that they have the right answer.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT12: They were able to recognise and describe these two behaviours for themselves - purely through their own playing and experimenting.
CONFIDENCESCORES.TEXT13: This also sparked a great conversation about when those different types of behaviours are appropriate. For some applications, such as a machine learning system used by doctors, they said they would want a cautious system that doesn't risk getting things wrong. For other applications, such as machine learning systems that recommend what song they should listen to next, it is better that the system tries when it has an answer, and is okay if it sometimes makes mistakes.
CONFIDENCESCORES.CALLOUT: Students learn how to effectively use confidence scores returned by machine learning models by playing, experimenting, and seeing the difference that different confidence thresholds make.

BLACKBOX.TITLE: There are ways to deal with the 'black box challenge'
BLACKBOX.TEXT1: This started out as a fun simple project. Students trained a machine learning model to recognise a few different toy figures.
BLACKBOX.TEXT2: For example, the machine learning model in the image shown here was trained to recognise The Doctor, Gandalf and a Ghostbuster.
BLACKBOX.TEXT3: The students were curious why their machine learning model was recognising each toy figure. What was it about that picture of The Doctor that the computer had learned to recognise as The Doctor?
BLACKBOX.TEXT4: There are adult developers that I've worked with who would declare that there is no way of knowing. They would say that machine learning models are a "black box" and that we can't tell anything about why they produce the output that they do.
BLACKBOX.TEXT5: What I love about working with children is that they can sometimes be less constrained by those kind of assumptions about things that "aren't possible".
BLACKBOX.TEXT6: They came up with some guesses. For example, the empty top-left corner probably wasn't significant, right?
BLACKBOX.TEXT7: We had some time in the lesson so I encouraged them to test their instincts.
BLACKBOX.TEXT8: They edited the image - covering up the patch they guessed wouldn't be significant, and then got the machine learning model to recognise the overall image again.
BLACKBOX.TEXT9: Their model still recognised the image as The Doctor, and the confidence in that was almost unchanged.
BLACKBOX.TEXT10: That seemed to confirm their guess: that part of the image wasn't significant in why the machine learning model recognised this as The Doctor.
BLACKBOX.TEXT11: They tried this again. This time they covered up the upper body.
BLACKBOX.TEXT12: Instinctively, they felt like it should be more signficant. Again, their testing appeared to confirm that.
BLACKBOX.TEXT13: The model still recognised it as The Doctor, but the confidence score had dropped by over 20%. This suggested that the body was a significant part of why the model recognised it as The Doctor.
BLACKBOX.TEXT14: Some of the results from their testing surprised them. Covering the left foot appeared to be very significant - it caused the confidence score to drop to fifty-six percent. I have no idea why, but it was very interesting to see!
BLACKBOX.TEXT15: They spent the rest of the lesson experimenting like this, covering different parts of the image, and seeing the difference it made to the confidence score each time.
BLACKBOX.TEXT16: I loved the way that lesson went, and I enjoyed watching the insight that they got from doing it. After the lesson I took this idea away and came up with a Scratch script that could automate what they'd done manually for themselves.
BLACKBOX.TEXT17: I made a Scratch script that moved that black sprite to every possible space on the webcam image, recording the difference it made to the confidence score at each location. Then I used those differences to make a visualisation. The visualisation put the black squares back, with the transparency set to be proportional to the difference it made to the confidence score.
BLACKBOX.TEXT18: The script created visualisations like this.
BLACKBOX.TEXT19: I showed the class the Scratch script in my next lesson with them the following week. It was just an automation of what they'd done for themselves. It was simple, but an effective way of giving a little insight into the question they'd asked me the week before: "What is it about this webcam picture that the machine learning model recognised as The Doctor?"
BLACKBOX.TEXT20: I loved that they'd found an answer for themselves, by playing, experimenting, and discussing, and all using Scratch blocks that they're familiar with already.
BLACKBOX.TEXT21: They did all of this in spite of the "black box challenge". Perhaps they benefitted from not starting from a position of thinking that it would not be possible.
BLACKBOX.CALLOUT: The flexibility of blocks in Scratch provide students with opportunities to explore the behaviour of machine learning models in creative ways.

LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TITLE: Machine learning doesn't always learn what we intend it to
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT1: Some of the best lessons I've run have been where a machine learning model did the "wrong" thing. Students learn a lot from seeing an example of machine learning not doing what we want.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT2: Perhaps my favourite example of when something went wrong was a lesson that I did on Rock, Paper, Scissors.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT3: Students make a Scratch project to play Rock, Paper, Scissors. They use their webcam to collect example photos of their hands making the shapes of rock (fist), paper (flat hand), and scissors (two fingers) - and use those photos to train a machine learning model to recognise their hand shapes.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT4: It this particular lesson, the project worked really nicely for nearly all the students. There was one student where things went a little bit wrong.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT5: This student had collected a decent set of training photos of their hand in a 'rock' shape. And a good set of training photos of their hand making a 'scissors' shape.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT6: While they were taking their training photos of their hand making the 'paper' shape, one of their friends in the class had come over to chat to them.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT7: Their friend was stood next to them while they were taking nearly all of these photos. And because of the way their webcam was angled, their friend was visible in nearly all the 'paper' training photos.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT8: None of us spotted that at first. None of us thought anything of it.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT9: Their machine learning model learned that a photo of a hand meant 'rock' or 'scissors', depending on the hand shape.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT10: But it learned that a photo of a hand and a person meant 'paper'.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT11: We only noticed this when the student started playing Rock, Paper, Scissors against the computer. When his teacher or I came around to see how he was getting on and stood by him, his machine learning model kept reporting that he was doing 'paper', whatever hand shape he made.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT12: For example, he'd have his hand in a 'rock' shape, but if we were stood by him, the machine learning model reported that he was doing 'paper'. When we stepped away, it correctly recognised he was doing 'rock'.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT13: It took us a little while to work out what was going on. When we eventually spotted what had happened, it became a fantastic, albeit unplanned, lesson for the class.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT14: I think they learned more from that one student's project than anything I had planned for the lesson.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT15: Because seeing things go wrong is such a useful experience for students, I don't always rely on it to happen in an unplanned way. Sometimes I have to resort to planting a trap if there's something I want students to see happen.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT16: For example, in one lesson, I helped students train a machine learning model to recognise whether a photo shows an apple or a tomato.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT17: I told them that I was saving them time by pointing them at where they could find images to use for training.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT18: You can probably see what I was planning with this from the screenshot: I'd pointed them at photos of green apples and red tomatoes.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT19: They used these to train a machine learning model.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT20: I helped them to make a test in Scratch - something that would take a new set of test photos and sort them into two groups: apples and tomatoes.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT21: Again, I told them that I was being helpful, and I gave them a set of test photos to use. But I gave them a bunch of photos of red apples, and (unripe) green tomatoes.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT22: Predictably, their machine learning models made many mistakes.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT23: Their models had learned that red objects are normally tomatoes, and green objects are normally apples. Because that's what we had taught it. But that isn't always true
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT24: That was a little contrived, but it was still useful. It got the students thinking about how things can go wrong and the things we can do to try and avoid that.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.TEXT25: Examples of this sort of mistake are sometimes reported in the media, such as an image classifier trained to recognise skin tumours that accidentally learned to recognise rulers in medical photos. Those are useful lessons, but seeing this happen for themselves gave that class a unique insight, whether it happens organically or is orchestrated and planned.
LEARNINGWRONGTHING.CALLOUT: Machine learning models learn from patterns in the training data that we give them, whether or not those are patterns we'd intended to give.

CONFUSED.TITLE: Inputs that aren't represented in training may not be recognised correctly
CONFUSED.TEXT1: Some of the best lessons I've run have been where a machine learning model did the "wrong" thing. Students learn a lot from seeing an example of machine learning not doing what we expect.
CONFUSED.TEXT2: In one lesson, I'd asked the class to find photos of cows and sheep, and use this to train a machine learning model. My plan was that we'd use this to make a virtual artificial intelligence sheepdog: something that could recognise photos of cows or sheep on a virtual farm, and sort them, moving each animal photo them to the correct area of the farm.
CONFUSED.TEXT3: To save time, I'd prepared the test photos for them - I collected photos of cows and sheep that they could use in a Scratch sheepdog project.
CONFUSED.TEXT4: This was the first time I ran this project, and one group of boys did something I hadn't expected. For their training examples, they'd collected a bunch of cartoon pictures of cows and sheep.
CONFUSED.TEXT5: When they ran the Scratch project, and tested their machine learning model with my photos of cows and sheep, it recognised everything as a sheep.
CONFUSED.TEXT6: I love it when things go wrong like that, because it leads to great conversations.
CONFUSED.TEXT7: The students said things like: "We've taught the computer to recognise cartoons. We didn't know you wanted it to recognise photos, so we didn't teach it how to do that. It hasn't learned to be able to recognise photos."
CONFUSED.TEXT8: I asked them what they thought we should do.
CONFUSED.TEXT9: One student said that my test pictures weren't fair, and that I should replace them with cartoon pictures - because their model should be able to sort that.
CONFUSED.TEXT10: Another student said that if they went back to their training examples and added photos, then their model could learn to recognise both cartoons and photos, and might do better at my test.
CONFUSED.CALLOUT: When students train a machine learning model to do one thing, they can see how it might not be very good at doing a different thing.

BIAS.TITLE: Bias and the responsibility of the machine learning developer
BIAS.TEXT1: Recommendation engines are a good topic for student projects. They're a common use of machine learning that most students will have interacted with before, such as streaming services recommending what song or video they might next want to listen to or watch. Making a simplified recommendation system for themselves is a good way for students to gain insight into how these systems are created.
BIAS.TEXT2: One example of the sort of projects I've done with students for this is to help them make an app that recommends places that someone might want to visit while on vacation. They do this by training a machine learning model using examples of how people might describe their likes and interests.
BIAS.TEXT3: Their app can then use this model to start making recommendations - they tell it what sort of thing that they like, and it uses that to suggest a place that they might like to visit.
BIAS.TEXT4: What I like about this project is giving students a little time to play and experiment and see what happens. For example, if they add two similar vacation places, such as a funfair and a theme park, how will their model handle that? I encourage them to try different ways of doing this.
BIAS.TEXT5: For example, students can try adding many, many training examples to their training bucket for 'theme park', and hardly any examples to their training bucket for 'funfair', and then see for themselves what happens.
BIAS.TEXT6: The result of doing this is typically that any time they mention about enjoying doing anything fun or exciting, or mention enjoying rides or adrenaline, then their app will recommend the theme park. Sometimes they can hardly get their app to recommend the funfair at all.
BIAS.TEXT7: I ask students why they think this happens, and they always immediately understand the cause. They might not use the same words that I might to describe it. They won't start talking about 'bias', for example, but they will explain why this happens by saying things like:
BIAS.TEXT8: "I've told the computer that the right answer is theme park loads of times"
BIAS.TEXT9: "I hardly ever told the computer that the right answer was funfair"
BIAS.TEXT10: I've seen this be a real surprise to students. Students often start out with an assumption that the machine learning systems with the "smartest" code or the "best" algorithms will give the correct answers. And that machine learning systems with "dumb" code or "bad" algorithms give the wrong answers.
BIAS.TEXT11: But what students see is that it isn't just that. In fact it isn't even mostly that. Rather the biggest impact on the way that the application behaves comes from the person who collects the training examples, and the way they collect the examples.
BIAS.TEXT12: That is often a real surprise, and a crucial insight for them to learn about machine learning projects.
BIAS.TEXT13: Once they understand how the machine learning tech behaves, through first-hand experimentation and experiences, I ask the students what they think of that.
BIAS.TEXT14: What if this was a real vacation recommendation app? What if it was really trained like this, to regularly recommend the theme park and rarely recommend the funfair?
BIAS.TEXT15: Many of them will still be unconcerned. They'll say things like "It's just a holiday app. It doesn't matter."
BIAS.TEXT16: I up the stakes by asking something like "What if you trained the app like this (to regularly recommend the theme park by putting many more training examples for the theme park) because the owner of the theme park gave you a big sack of cash? Is that still okay?"
BIAS.TEXT17: At this point, as money is involved, some of the class start to change their mind. Some of them start to argue that this would be a bad thing. But not all - some of them will still be unconcerned about the way that a holiday app is created.
BIAS.TEXT18: So I up the stakes further and ask "What if this was an AI app for doctors? What if this app was recommending the best medicine to give, based on a description of someone's symptoms? What if the person training the app made sure they used a lot of training examples of when one particular medicine was the best choice, and hardly any examples of when another medicine was the best choice? And what if they did all of this because the manufacturer of azaphine gave them a big sack of cash?"
BIAS.TEXT19: At this point, most of the class will start to be concerned. I've heard primary school students make amazingly thoughtful and passionate arguments about ethics in AI, the need for oversight in how AI is used in fields like medicine, and the need for transparency in training data used for machine learning applications in critical applications.
BIAS.TEXT20: They didn't use any of those words, but children have an innate sense of justice, what they think is fair, and what they think is right and wrong. With a little insight into what is possible, they are entirely able to engage intelligently in these kinds of debates.
BIAS.CALLOUT: By experimenting with their own machine learning model, students can see how easy it is to introduce bias into AI applications - which enables them to engage in debates on ethics in AI.

SOLUTIONS.TITLE: Combining machine learning models can make a powerful app
SOLUTIONS.TEXT1: Once students have made a few simple projects, I like to help them to make a project that includes multiple machine learning models.
SOLUTIONS.TEXT2: For example, 'Laser Eyes' is a project where students need to shoot bottles using laser beams from their eyes, by moving their head to the right place and then shouting 'Laser Eyes!'.
SOLUTIONS.TEXT3: It's a fun and silly game, made using a combination of two machine learning models: a face detection model to recognise where their eyes are in the webcam, and a sound machine learning model that they have to train to recognise when they shout out 'Laser Eyes'.
SOLUTIONS.TEXT4: There are many other ways to make something that blends multiple models.
SOLUTIONS.TEXT5: For example, I've helped students make chatbots that combine three machine learning models: one text model that they train to recognise the meaning of the question that has been asked, a second text model that they train to recognise when the use of language in the questions suggest that the user is getting annoyed or frustrated, and a third speech to text model that means someone can ask questions without having to type.
SOLUTIONS.TEXT6: This sort of project is a good choice when I'm working with a class over multiple weeks, as each new week I can introduce a new use of machine learning that they can add to an existing app that we build up over time. The final result is often very impressive!
SOLUTIONS.TEXT7: I've found that assembling a solution from a blend of multiple machine learning models helps students to recognise uses of AI/ML in the world around them. When they think of the relationship between a machine learning model and the main function of an app as being a one-to-one relationship, they only recognise the most obvious and visible AI applications where the primary function of the app is a machine learning capability. But when they start to think of machine learning as offering a tiny capability as part of a larger app doing multiple things, it starts to open their eyes up to many other possible uses of machine learning. They start to recognise how artificial intelligence is all around us.
SOLUTIONS.CALLOUT: Helping students to create an application that combines multiple machine learning models gives them a much more realistic insight into the way that the technologies are used in the real-world.

MISUSING.TITLE: What happens when machine learning models are used for things they weren't trained to do
MISUSING.TEXT1: Once students have an understanding of what machine learning technologies can do and how they behave, I like to get them thinking about how they should be used.
MISUSING.TEXT2: For this project, I had two small groups of students.
MISUSING.TEXT3: I asked one group of students to train a computer to recognise photos of fruit. They chose a few types of fruit (plum, banana, pear) and started collecting training images of each to use to train a machine learning model.
MISUSING.TEXT5: I asked the other group of students to train a computer to recognise photos of creatures. They chose a few types of creature (fish, insect, bird) and started collecting training images of each to use to train a machine learning model.
MISUSING.TEXT7: I didn't tell them what we'd be using these for until they'd finished.
MISUSING.TEXT8: Once their machine learning models were ready, I revealed what we'd be doing: asking the computer to recognise ink blot pictures.
MISUSING.TEXT9: We made a Scratch project that would show an inkblot image to both of the groups' machine learning models.
MISUSING.TEXT10: Given the same inkblot image, one of the models recognised it as a fish, insect, or bird. The other model recognised the same image as a plum, banana, or pear. Both machine learning models were trained using the same technology, yet were giving very different answers to the same question.
MISUSING.TEXT11: When I asked the students to explain why this would happen, they intuitively gave sensible explanations:
MISUSING.TEXT12: "We've only trained this model to be able to recognise things as fish/insect/bird so that is all it knows how to do"
MISUSING.TEXT13: "We've taught this model that everything is either a fish, insect, or bird so it's learned that everything is either a fish, insect, or bird"
MISUSING.TEXT14: My reason for getting them to work through this was a machine learning project that had received some media coverage a year or so earlier. The project, called 'Norman', involved training a machine learning system to recognise images from horror films, and then using that model to generate descriptions of ink blot images. What the students had created was a much-simplified version of that same project, with a similar outcome.
MISUSING.TEXT15: The students went through a collection of the media reports about the 'Norman' project, and discussed what they thought of the way the project was described in the media.
MISUSING.TEXT16: A lot of the media coverage relied on anthropomorphizing the machine learning model - describing how the AI had been "traumatized" by being forced to "watch" a lot of horror films. From their experience making a similar project, the students saw it differently, describing it as a model that has been trained to recognise that everything is a scene from a horror film, so all it has learned to do is describe scenes from horror films. The media coverage described the machine learning model as being a psychopath. The students discussed whether they thought that a machine learning model that has only been trained with negative or upsetting images should be described as having a psychiatric disorder.
MISUSING.TEXT17: What I liked most out of that lesson was that it got the students to think critically about how artificial intelligence is portrayed in the media, and to start forming their own opinions about the issues raised there.
MISUSING.CALLOUT: If machine learning models are used to do something that is very different to what they were trained to do, the results might be unexpected or invalid.

INVISIBLEAI.TITLE: Invisible artificial intelligence systems are everywhere
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT1: In this project, students trained a machine learning model to recognise the first bit of the postcode for a few local cities. (For non-UK readers, this is equivalent to something like a zip-code or perhaps the two-letter abbreviation for a name of a state or county).
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT2: They did this by drawing examples of how those postal codes are written, directly onto an on-screen canvas.
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT3: They used this to make a game in Scratch based on the children's television show Postman Pat, where they would write a postcode onto an on-screen envelope, and their machine learning model would recognise what they had written and move the envelope to the correct Postman Pat van.
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT4: My goal for the project was to introduce them to the idea of using machine learning for handwriting recognition, and optical character recognition in general. Instead of just telling them that this tech exists, they learned about it through playing and experimenting with a simplified version that created themselves. Although their own models could only recognise a few letters, this was still enough to help them understand what was possible.
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT5: While they were interested in the technology, what seemed to have the biggest impact on the students was the idea that artificial intelligence is used when they post a letter. This was something that they hadn't thought of before. It opened up their eyes to the idea that AI systems are all around us. They started asking questions about where else machine learning models are used.
INVISIBLEAI.TEXT6: The takeaway for the lesson was that it got them thinking about how they interact with artificial intelligence systems every day, even when they don't directly see it.
INVISIBLEAI.CALLOUT: Creating projects based on real-world applications of machine learning is an effective way to open up students' eyes to the fact that AI systems are all around them, and impact their lives in countless unseen ways.
